forumNotes.author: mightymouse
forumNotes.content:
Several months ago I needed to help an elderly relative  
who has two old desktops. They're in good condition,  
because I've replaced 90% of the hardware in both  
of them.  

I've got many portable diagnostic apps on bootable CDs  
and USB sticks. Old desktops can't boot from either, but  
PLoP came to the rescue. I used v5.0.3 and created a  
simple PLoP floppy. I selected CDROM or USB from the  
menu. It worked perfectly!  

Recently, I got a call from the same relative, because he  
needed help again with his desktops. I didn't keep the  
original PLoP floppy, so I created a new one in a few minutes.  
For some reason, PLoP keeps telling me all my bootable CDs  
are not bootable. I downloaded the latest version - 5.0.8.  
Same problem!  

I'm a command line junkie going back 30 years, so I have  
no trouble performing simple or complex operations from  
the command line.  

I posted on the PLoP forum. Elmar, the creator of PLoP  
doesn't have a solution.  

I tested my bootable CDs on several modern desktops that  
all have a seperate BIOS utility that allows you to boot from  
a wide range of devices. There is nothing wrong with any of  
my bootable CDs.  

Both old desktops have CDROM and CDRW drives. PLoP  
identifies them correctly, when you select CDROM from the  
menu.  

Elmar has made it incredibly easy to create a working floppy  
with PLoP.  

I've tried some crazy things, like creating the same floppy  
with different brands of disks. There is only one anomally  
when I create a PLoP floppy. The starfield graphical theme  
doesn't work. The only thing I remember about the original  
working floppy is the starfield and the menu. I didn't use the  
"stf" parameter with the working disk, but the starfield  
appeared anyway. When I attempt to recreate the disk, the  
starfield doesn't appear, even if I use the "stf=on" parameter.  
I don't care about the starfield one way or the other, but  
maybe the failure of the starfield is part of a larger problem  
which is causing PLoP to list all bootable CDs as not bootable.  

Elmar was very kind. He tried to help, but all he could say  
was "very strange." I agree with him!  

There is something wrong, but I'm at a dead end. Before I  
abandon PLoP, maybe a forum member can help me.

Rawwritewin uses plpbt.img, but plpbt.bin is the file written onto the  
floppy. An app like WinImage can format a disk and write the bin  
file in one operation.  

If you try to configure plpbt.bin from version 5.0.3, with plpcfgbt.exe  
from the zip archive 0.7 it won't work. Bring up a command prompt  
in Windows and try it. You'll get an error message. You have to use  
one of the early versions of plpcfgbt.exe with a compatible bin file.  
That's why I searched Google, hoping to find versions 0.3 - thru - 0.6.   

I appreciate the link for v0.4. I'd like to find the others. The more  
versions I've got, the better my chances are of creating a working  
disk.

I tried every combination of words I could think of with Google to

I am actually very calm, rest assured. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Then, are you going to leave "the game" or are you willing to go on looking for the problem? ![:smiling9:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/smiling9.gif) If you are still wiht us, there are not so many things you can actually configure through plpcfgbt: ``` Usage: plpcfgbt [OPTIONS] file Options: ======== PARAM SET VALUES #1 vm video mode text, 640x480, 800x600, 1024x768, 1280x1024 #2 stm start mode menu or hidden, hidden requires cnt=on and dbt not off #3 cnt countdown on or off #4 cntval countdown value in seconds between 1 and 99 #4 dbt default boot off, profile, floppy, cdrom, usb #5 prf profile value between 1 and 16 #6 stf starfield on or off #7 zan zoom animation on or off #8 fnt font bt or bios #9 usb1 force usb 1.1 on or off #10 int19h int19h/os boot do not boot the os and use int19h, on or off #11 hotkey startup hotkey yes or no ```
Settings #1 to #8 and #11 seem more like "cosmetic" or "interface" settings and cannot possibly change the booting behaviour, so the only two settings that may have actually a relevance should be #9 and #10. If I were you I would play with those two only. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.content:
Hi, I am also versed in electronics and have been using computers for years.  

Can we take a step back from PLoP for a minute?  

I remember how unreliable floppy disks and drives were, and still are. In fact, you could create a floppy on one computer and bring it to another computer and it wouldn't read.  

Why? Misalignment of the floppy read/write heads. So let me ask you this... Did you create the floppy boot disk using the same drive you are trying to boot it with? If not, could you create a boot disk on your relative's computer, or install your floppy drive on his computer?  

Another solution I would suggest is ditching the whole boot from CD-ROM or USB method.  

Why not install a cheap small hard drive as the master IDE, install whatever OS your relative uses on the drive and whatever diagnostic and fix-it tools you need, then install his main drive after that as a slave, and use your "rescue fixed disk" to repair his computer? That way you have a sure way to boot, and you can diagnose hardware, work with his disk while it is offline, etc. When done, obviously revert it back to normal.  

It is a bit more work, you have to disassemble the PC, but it is a good excuse to blow out the dust inside, if any.  

Finally, if this user of yours is having MS Windows related issues due to malware or viruses, and his needs are not specialized, I would suggest he try Linux instead. Depending on the distro it is super easy to use and has a full suite of apps and drivers ready to go. The distro to use depends on the power of the PC. Anyway, I use Linux Mint 7 XFCE which has a light weight but full featured desktop with familiar controls (compared to Windows), and it runs rock solid and detected all of my hardware and installed flash, etc out of the box. I don't have to defrag, virus scan, or any of that nonsense anymore. Boot times are fast also. It's not for everyone, just a suggestion.  

breaker
